comments.commentBody: Mr. Thomason, I am glad you brought that up. Frenemy Saudi refused to open an Embassy after the fall of Saddam and help the reconstruction because, as you alluded to, they just would not get their head around the notion of an Shia majority (Sykes Picot artificial) Iraq State run by a Shia government.

During our entire war in Iraq, the Saudis refused to recognize the government we were fighting to support. They didn't send an ambassador, and wouldn't help. Instead, Saudi individuals were privately funding the Sunni extremists we fought.

Now the Iraq government does not get along with the Saudis? It was always that way. That isn't news. It is misleading to suggest it is news.

Iraq become a Lebanon? Iraq has been far worse than Lebanon for a decade. They've had as many as 5,000 killed each month this year.

This isn't about Yemen. The Saudis oppose the Iraqis, and always have.

In fact Yemen isn't really about Yemen. It is really just a proxy war, with the Sunnis on the offensive as they have been in Iraq against us for a decade.

It is very inconvenient that the Saudis are the US enemy here, but it is a fact anyway. It has been since 9/11.

Yes, they indigenous Yemenis.

They are not either Sunnis or Shiites. They are unlike both the Saudis and Iranians. They have their very own offshoot of Islam, that both of the large groups reject.

Think of it as Catholics and Protestants fighting each other for control of a Mormon country, because one faction of Mormons tossed out the other faction.
Don't worry...I'm sure he's not interested in going to Arizona.

Ain't that the truth. Shamefully, only 26% of eligible New Yorker voters cast a vote in the election that DeBlasio won....the turnout was appalling - one can only hope that more voters will get to the polls after see the messes DeBlasio has made...

Thank you mayor.  We need more public figures speaking out for progressive views.   Right now the so called "centrists" have been pulled to the right since so many conservative politicans get the attention of the media.  With the exception of Senator Sanders and Senator Warren, we see and hear little from the left.  The republicans, if they get their way, want to make the Presidental race about foreign policy since  they have nothing to offer on income inequality other than endorsing it.  The more attention that can be gotten for progressive ideas the better.

So our pushover of a mayor thinks he can lead a national leftward movement?

This is the same mayor who, after angering the NYPD for daring to suggest that maybe cops should be held accountable for misconduct, is now so cowed by the police department that he essentially asks "how high" every time they say "jump."

This is the same mayor who, after going on and on about the need for affordable housing in the city, has pretty much given up on anything but lip service, and has let real estate interests run roughshod over the city.

Or the same mayor whose solution to the worsening competence of the MTA (not to mention its crumbling infrastructure) is to start a campaign telling people to "call their congressman"?

If "the left" is taking this ineffectual weakling as its leader, "the left" isn't going to be taken very seriously in this next election cycle.

A former Demcrat, born in Group-Think, Massachusetts - I voted for a Republican during the last two elections and it felt WONDERFUL......methinks the Democrat Party has seen better days; it lacks fresh ideas, energy and vision....JFK of the "ask-not-what-your-country-do-for-you-but-what- you-can-do-for-your-country" would be stunned and saddened to lay witness to the current Democrat cries of identity politics, political correctness, anti-free market policies and class warfare. Be brave - jump and vote with conviction for REAL CHANGE.

I am not discounting the benefits of exercise.  However, I believe people routinely lie when filling out surveys.  So, I always wonder how skewed the results are on studies about frequency of sex, frequency of exercise, and frequency of charitable donations.
No, they don't. Easy to get used to and the benefits are apparent very fast.

Quote from the Harvard study abstract: "We used Cox proportional hazards regression with cohort stratification to generate multivariable-adjusted hazard ratios (HRs) and 95% CIs."

Sounds like in the Harvard study, they did adjust for other factors such as diet. In any case, they were trying to find out if here was an upper limit on healthy amounts of exercise, and have pretty good evidence here tat there is not.

Is your point that longevity has only to do with diet and not exercise? Why would you believe that health is affected by what you eat but not by how much you exercise?

What is your PROBLEM??? Is it not simply self-evident that exercise will produce good results?  We dont really need scientific studies to tell us that our bodies and our brains will benefit greatly, from increased use.

My siblings and I have the same genes.  I exercise, they don't, and it shows.  People can keep telling themselves that exercise is not important, but I know how it makes me feel and there is no question I do better when I can move.  Even those who are sick or restricted can do things like breathing exercises or ones which do not raise the heart rate.  A friend of mine recovering from cancer and mastectomy is doing this and feeling much better.  10 years ago I had a major illness during which i was bedridden for months and I have come back from that.

Both of these observational studies are fatally flawed by two well-known epidemiological study biases.

The first is called "selection bias." You simply don't have evenly representative or randomized populations in each study cohort. Many people in the most-sedentary cohort are there for a reason: unlucky genes or underlying metabolisms/morbidity that make them less inclined or less able to exercise to begin with. They are going to have morbidity or mortality problems before those able to more strenuously exercise regardless of whether they drag themselves to exercise or not. It is the bad health outcomes of these people that drive the resulting hazard rates.

The second reason is "healthy user" confounders in the exerciser cohorts that are not accounted for in the study equation models. Many people who care enough about their health to exercise frequently will similarly practice better health habits like better diets, more preventive screenings, better prescription medication compliance, etc. The health outcome effects of the hundred more health-conscious habits of these people were not considered in the study models and so end up erroneously attributed to exercise instead of to the coincident health-conscious behaviors themselves.

It is in the financial interests of the exercise-orthopedic-industrial-complex and health reporter/cheerleaders to continue to (intentionally?) ignore these absolutely fatal flaws. Don't believe this hooey.

Cmd - So you "can no longer run due to injuries"? Sounds a lot like cigarette smoking to me. You do something unhealthy until it injures you. I genuinely feel sorry for you. That has happened to just about all of my strenuous-exerciser friends. They do it until they harm themselves so badly that they cannot do it any more. Every one of them. And the medical establish considers this desirable? (But they keep many orthopedic hospital doctors in their expensive cars...)

You "miss the endorphins"? Sounds like drug abuse to me. But self-pleasure or self-medication from running won't get you thrown in jail at least...

mr big - why is it that stressing any other part of your body long-term produces morbidity--your carpal tunnel, your eyes, your liver, your joints--but stressing your cardiovascular system long-term somehow miraculously produces health?  The fact is, like with every other body part, it doesn't.  Just wishful thinking.  (Or economic thinking if you are in the wellness-resources business...)

My husband recently was prescribed a CPAP machine and he adjusted to it instantly and perfectly. It has completely controlled his snoring and sleep apnea. I only wish he had gotten this 20 years ago. I recognize it doesn't work for everyone but don't be afraid to try if you qualify - it is a miracle for us.

It's backwards. Barring accidents and or congenital problems, for most people we do less physical exertion Therefore we we feel less well. It wasn't this way in agrarian times will little help from machines. But that not negate the primary impulse we have to move -- otherwise would have ended up on our back never having learnt to stand much less walk, run and jump.

PacNWGuy - Absolutely! In order to recommend that otherwise sedentary people should dramatically change their behavior and practice modest-to-strenuous exercise 180-hrs per week you require a randomized long-term hard-outcome trial with a large, otherwise sedentary population that changes their behavior and practice modest-to-strenuous exercise 180-hrs per week. Follow them and an identical control group for 5 or 10 years and see if there is a significant difference in hard outcomes.

To recommend changes based on observational studies fatally-flawed by "selection bias" and "healthy-user confounders" is, frankly, malpractice. Studies and articles like this are going to, literally, unnecessarily kill people. Shame.
The Saudis always opposed the Iraqi government set up by the US. They didn't even recognize it or send an ambassador. The Iraqis could not possibly turn to them instead of Iran.

Children are the most resourceful when it comes to finding a way to become more vigorously engaged: they jump in place, walk up and down the steps in an aprtment, run ahead of you on sidewalks. So as an adult this is what I do to get some sweat and heart rate in the "zone" -- I swing my leg clockwise and anticlockwise for 12 minutes. And I walk, sun, snow or rain, out of desire for walk.

I work out extremely hard 4 times weekly...cardio and resistance....but I spend the rest of the week completely idle. Feet up on the desk staring at computer screen, or on a couch. I think I represent a good portion of the modern American populace. Wonder what our odds are...

Plus I have no clue how to fix a washer. Fortunately there's something called Angie's List on that computer.
Yes, good point. All of them.

There is almost a reverse stigmatism to being fit.  I have people telling me I am naturally thin.  Lucky that I can eat anything I want and remain skinny because of some supposedly hereditary condition.  NO, and No.    I don't spend the week in the gym but I don't sit on my butt either.  I haven't watched TV in fifteen years. I don't hire others to do chores for me either.  I fix the washer, I paint the house, I plant the garden, I change the oil, I do all the stuff others pay someone else to do so they can play video games or watch TV.
mt. sutro behind parnassus is a great place to run.  there are trails halfway up.
I ran a lot of marathons in my day, and I also walked up and down those San Francisco hills for a week.  What a pain in the ...

Walking UPhill is THE best exercise, if you ask me.  When I lived in San Francisco and walked those hilly and steep streets daily, i was in the best shape ever.  Combine this with yoga and working out at the gym at least once a week.  Driving a car everywhere is one of the worst things you can do to your body !!

Mary - Absolutely! This is formally called "selection bias" in observational studies such as these and it makes their numbers and conclusions meaningless. It amazes me that a paper as good as The New York Times continues to ignore this.

Also, people do care enough about their health to exercise regularly also tend to care about their diets, their preventive screenings, their prescription adherence, their safety belts, etc. more than people who don't make the effort to exercise conscientiously. But the some total of the effects of heath conscientiousness get erroneously attributed to "exercise" instead of to health conscientiousness. Studies like this are hooey!

One needn't be overweight to have sleep apnea.
Why not participate in a study if you have symptoms?

Don't know anything about sleep apnea. I'm 58 and I recollect for many years when I was younger I would lay in bed on the verge of waking up and realize (or think) that perhaps I was not breathing for extended periods. I thought at the time I must be breathing because I would not have been able to hold my breath for so long. But I definitely went for extended periods (I have no idea how long), without breathing.

I don't know if I have sleep apnea now since my wife says I snore and won't stay in the same room. Mmmmm.

I'm not overweight.
Did you perhaps mean CPAP, or is there some other device called BPAP I've never heard of?
Ben, yes there is.  Do a search with terms BPAP and apnea.
BPAP is a machine which puts out a high breath in pressure and then lowers the pressure so that you have a more normal pressure to exhale against.  It is for severe sleep apnea.

My wife has slept the last several years with ear plugs due to my snoring.  My doctor strongly suggested that I needed a sleep test which I resisted for a while but finally agreed.   It showed I had severe sleep apnea and I was given a BPAP machine with a nasal mask about a year ago.   I use it every night and sleep easily from 7-9 hours.  One time I failed to take it with us on a week long trip and I slept so poorly I will not do that again.  My wife no longer needs ear plugs, I wake up rested.  I think like so many things success or failure with the BPAP depends on your attitude about it.   I was determined from night one to make it work and it has.    Since my first wife died of Alzheimer's I found this article very interesting and anything that might help avoid that horror should be embraced.

Actually, it does hurt.  As an old retired fogey, I can say that all of my exercise-conscious friends exercised until the exercise itself caused them such harm (usually orthopedic) that they could not continue.  Self-harm, basically.  but it kept a lot of trainers and orthopedic doctors employed...

"wasn't Yemen being touted as an example of how well our strategy in the Middle East was working?"

Compared to what? It was working better than the rest. The rest are still as much of a mess as Yemen at its worst.

If Mr. de Blasio is really concerned about establishing a progressive political force in this country, he should not just think about domestic policies but also concentrate on foreign and military policy. For some progressives, such as me, foreign and military policy is much more important than domestic policy. Indeed, it is the incredibly stupid and criminal mistakes of the US over the last fifty years in the area of foreign policy and military engagements which makes me so down on the US at the present.

In this area there can be no more important advice than for Mr. de Blasio to not follow the typical course of politicians in the US of being "stooges" for the belligerent state of Israel. This may be a hard task for a New York City mayor, but it is absolutely essential if he is going to truly work for what is good for the world and for America. As a progressive I am absolutely fed up with the manner in which politicians from both parties pander to Israel to the detriment of America and the world.

The fact that he has not endorsed Hillary is a good sign. She has aptly demonstrated over the time in which she was in office what a war monger she is. If Hillary becomes president, it will be like America has elected a reincarnated Margaret Thatcher to be president.

It would be lovely to see a woman as president of the US, but the US should not elect any unqualified woman who comes along just to say we have a woman president.
